author: nishant0
content:
for the PR above 
> Gossipsub peers are separate from the ETH2 RPC protocol, and thus cannot
> rely on the application-level Status negotiation to establish if
> they're on the same network.

Unless I am missing something, will there ever be a situation where our peers from eth2 rpc will be different from our gossip peers ?

author: arnetheduck
content: they are separate protocols, you can ostensibly create a peer that does only gossip for example. also, the application-level negotiation of `Status` happens separately from gossipsub - the flow is such that you generally shouldn't have to wait for RPC to connect to gossip

author: arnetheduck
content: in fact, to implement a correct sync protocol, you should start collecting gossip attestations/blocks before you start requesting blocks - this makes it easier to avoid some race conditions that would otherwise require more complex logic to deal with

author: nishant0
content: also I can see that there would be a subset of peers that only want to participate in gossip and not rpc

author: jgm
content: What is the chain ID equivalent here? Or are we assuming no overlap on fork versions (which seems brave)

author: arnetheduck
content: hoping for non-overlapping chain id's is equally brave

author: arnetheduck
content: but in general, I haven't seen much rationale around the fork version design or any recommendations for typical uses (ie forking) - one could in theory separate versions of the same "socially agreed" chain (ETH hard forks) and the same version of different chains (ETH vs ETC), but the distinction is somewhat fuzzy - one would encode the ruleset, the other the social bit, maybe, but it's questionable whether that's a meaningful distinction

author: jgm
content:
> hoping for non-overlapping chain id's is equally brave

I would say the difference is that setting a chain ID is a one-off activity that takes place at the time of the split and creates a separate domain that can be relatively easily tracked external to the protocol.  Keeping track of all fork versions across all products that share a similar root would be an on-going problem that would need to be revisited each time a chain went ahead with a fork.

author: jgm
content: Agree that there is not a lot out there in terms of the forking process, however.
